content: So maybe we can start by assembling a list of things to think about this year. I'm also curious to find out who might be interested in helping out with some of the coordination work. But let's start by naming out things to be done...
• we wanted to cull down some of the questions from last year, I think, since we had the impression survey was getting too long
• there was a list of lessons from last year's survey, can someone post a link to that document?
I probably have that document somewhere in paper or Google docs, I can try and find it.
Something we probably also want to consider is should we have survey questions related to COVID-19?
Also how does everyone feels about using Google Forms again? I remember having quite a few frustrations with using it, but I don’t really know of a better alternative.
that about sums it up :)
There's a family of questions I would really love to ask. People talk in freeform comments about Rust compilation time. I'd like to add 2-3 structured questions about it.
We should put "compile time" in one of the "prioritize this list of things you care about" questions.
And I'd love to ask "how powerful is the system you most commonly do compiles on?" (number of CPUs and amount of RAM).

(Disclosure: I'd like to know that information for several reasons, including understanding how much the community cares about it, and how effective various solutions may be. I also have a professional interest in that information.)
I should hope that every single response ranks it as the number 1 priority (though perhaps only 99% of people will).
I don't know whether that's what would happen or not. I can easily imagine people prioritizing other things.

XAMPPRocky said:

I probably have that document somewhere in paper or Google docs, I can try and find it.

I've dug into my mailbox and found this one
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1hUJ_76ufq_5-qlBftgEgpa8EHXpznklAk-pdRryS1mM/edit

To my knowledge, this was the internal official feedback document

I was also curious to find a good alternative to Forms (also for personal reference, can always come in handy).
A super quick search while sipping coffee led to:

  • https://dislack.com/pricing (only Plus/Pro tiers would suit for our needs)
  • https://forms.id/ (seems interesting)
  • https://www.userreport.com/ (lots of buzzwords and moving stuff, couldnt figure out at a glance the features of a free tier)

This weekend I hope I can spare some time investigating one or more of these alternatives

In my opinion, a replacement to Forms should tick the following (in this order):

  • allow questions custom flow (like we had last year: conditional jump to section if answer yes/no)
  • responsive design / allow mobile users
  • bulk load questions (ideally from an export of Pontoon)
  • dump answers in a open format (e.g. csv)
  • FLOSS and privacy aware service
I think maybe @Jasun Carr might have useful data here, I think when he and I talked about it last time, he felt that Google forms was the thing to use, despite its flaws.
So, I'm not sure whether we'll be able to do contracting or not
I think probably it's best to assume not
and think about whether we can pull off the survey without it
maybe a good time to try and simplify the survey considerably :)
I agree, maybe we should start with what questions we’d like to see return from last year? https://blog.rust-lang.org/2020/04/17/Rust-survey-2019.html
I was thinking something similar
my sense already was that the survey was way too long regardless, and that a lot of the feedback is ultimately not that "actionable"

I think these are some questions we probably want to keep. I don’t know if we want to split analysis/questions between people who are working full-time and those who are not like last year. If only because it doubles the amount of work.

  • What editor do you use?
  • What platform(s) do you develop on?
  • What platform(s) do you develop for?
  • What industries do you work in?
  • How many dependencies are 1.0?
  • What languages do you want better interop with?
@XAMPPRocky consolidating questions makes sense to me
I wonder if it makes sense to setup a meeting next week to talk stuff over and try to come up with a first draft?
or if you want to edit the workflow async, that's ok too
I’d be up for having a meeting, though I’m not sure how many people would we’d have in that timeframe.
I guess a good question is what people are best to loop in
but I am thinking maybe late next week, like Friday, which would also give us a bit more time to iterate before-hand (and I imagine a ZUlip meeting, to make it easier for folk to catch up)
one thing I was wondering is .. which teams actually use information and what do they use?
I could start by going over the survey for myself and writing out the information that I've found helpful
I have definitely looked to the survey for inspiration for time to time

I think you are correct with your list, but there are some questions missing, I definitely feel like some of the larger scope questions ("which parts are confusing", "how long did it take for you to get used to things") have been helpful too
another thing to look at would be "which questions did we talk about in the blog posts"

Yeah those are good questions to ask. Maybe we should send an email (or a ping in zulip maybe?) ahead of the meeting to the leads; saying that we are thinking about how what questions to include and if there's anything they'd be particularly interested in? It could give us something to start with.
That sounds good @XAMPPRocky
I was thinking that project leads was probably a good resource to reach out to
Just posting about it in #project leads (public) should be enough right? It's not really a sensitive discussion AFAICT.
agreed
@XAMPPRocky I was giving this some thought. I think we should just run the exact same survey as last year (tweaked only as needed)
basic idea: too much going on
this will minimize the work needed to get survey out the door
In particular, in a core team meeting today we were discussing roadmap process and looking at calendar and thinking that we would ideally launch survey by Sep 3
which is...in 1 week
but if we run with the existing survey + existing translations
then this is much more plausible
we do want to start trying to wrangle up a "translation team" thouh
Hello
Hey @technetos =)
You can see my last few comments with up to date thinking :)
Just finished reading through them
in short, I am thinking about how we can get the survey up-and-going as quickly as possible this year (versus running it late like we did last year)
We dont know what questions we want to ask right?
Well, we have the surveys from pervious years
They had flaws
but ..
we did have an explicit doc of lessons from last year that we should review
but in general I think we could run the survey again, in general continuinty is a positive thing anyway so I wouldn't have expected to make massive changes
(I had some idea to filter out some questions, and we could even still do that)
we also have all the translations from last year
(I have to find the whole list)
I think most of the work that needs doing is to wrangle up translators
i.e., to translate people's responses
and translate any questions we want to add
I'm proposing we add 0 questions :)
but yes
Ok, out as fast as possible
Yeah, it's not optimal, I hate to rush, but at the same time... I'd rather be out on time.
Do you have that lessons learned document?
looking
@technetos https://docs.google.com/document/d/1hUJ_76ufq_5-qlBftgEgpa8EHXpznklAk-pdRryS1mM/edit
I guess I imagine that a 1 or 2h sync meeting could plausibly prep the work for release
there were some thoughts (e.g., collapsing duplicate questions) that would make life easier, and I could imagine doing that, but it also seems like a fair amount of work
Yeah any significant change or removal will at least require translator work to make sure it syncs up.
right
I think that removing the duplicate/similar questions would be a good goal. I also agree that checking those across the different translations would take time
I feel like we could start working on the Rust 2021 survey :)
but still run the Rust 2020 survey as is
We could make no change at all and be very honest in the announcement about why there is no change.
Do we even have to talk about it much? Like, do people expect surveys to change?
I guess I think that overall you do want to minimize the change in the survey regardless to ensure results can be compared across years
yeah if anything this will give us a decent 1:1 comparison
No I guess not, but people who submitted feedback on last years questions will presumably run into those same issues again this year.
what updates need to be made to the existing survey so that its ready to be released this year?
date changes, so on.

nikomatsakis said:

but still run the Rust 2020 survey as is

Possibly controversial idea but ... do we really need to run the survey this year after all? If we don't have bandwidth to prepare that, I kind of assume there's no bandwidth also for parsing the results.

XAMPPRocky said:

No I guess not, but people who submitted feedback on last years questions will presumably run into those same issues again this year.

^ this
We should run the survey in some form, for sure
Is the survey stored in a repo somewhere?
as far as I know it's a set of google polls (one per language)
Gotcha

Lokathor said:

We should run the survey in some form, for sure

I think, too. But on the other hand I wonder if having close results as last year will provide actionable data to plan for something else that the team doesnt already know
and make 2021 a really excellent survey
the exact point of the survey is that we don't know the results before we run the survey. @apiraino

Particularly the Rust Ecosystem moves faster than seemingly any other programming ecosystem. The 2018 Rustconf keynote about using the specs ecs crate is already old tech compared to the new ecs crates. Error crates also have wild turn-over. Async is much more used. I'm sure we could go on.

So we need new survey info even if it's an identical survey.
What is the time frame for getting the survey out?
We are aiming for end of next week 2020, and 2021 is likely a similar timeline (i.e., early September).
(Yes it is known that that is Really Soon; if we must slip then that will happen).
hmm, i dont think we have any time for translating new questions or verifying in each translation if a removed question makes sense.
That is my impression too -- it was my understanding though that that is not interesting
er, not necessary
"nice to have"
indeed
I can help for French translation if this is needed

yes, last year we had a group of people (me included) that volunteered to translate questions and then answers. Could be a good idea to contact them all again. With an even shorter notice than last year, apparently
(don't know who took care of that last year. Some contacts were handled by @Santiago Pastorino )

simulacrum said:

We are aiming for end of next week 2020, and 2021 is likely a similar timeline (i.e., early September).

By the way, what will be the differences between these two polls? I imagine something along the line of:
Survey 2020: what was your 2020 in Rust?
Survey 2021: what would you like to be your 2021 in Rust?

If yes, I kind of see a partial overlap when the 2020 survey will ask the "what would you like to see improved/stabilized?" kind of question. I believe that sounds like implicitely the first question for the 2021 survey

apiraino said:

yes, last year we had a group of people (me included) that volunteered to translate questions and then answers. Could be a good idea to contact them all again. With an even shorter notice than last year, apparently

Well, if there are no new questions, it's not shorter notice
But yes @Santiago Pastorino did manage the communication and coordination of translations last year, I presume he has a list of folks
(In other words, we don't have to start translating until the results are coming available)
the list of contacts is in the spreadsheet we've used
can you link that spreadsheet?
couldn't find it, tomorrow will try to look again for it but meanwhile ...
@nikomatsakis @XAMPPRocky do you remember where did we place these documents
I know they lived in Google Drive
could find https://docs.google.com/document/d/1hUJ_76ufq_5-qlBftgEgpa8EHXpznklAk-pdRryS1mM/edit#heading=h.f1no0b5ln6t0, notes about things to improve
but I can't find the spreadsheet where we had all the contacts
there we go https://docs.google.com/document/d/1l_tjLx6euqlyz6Wlk9vSggKMtV-be6bAEdGaQE9-TYg/edit
here is the drive https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/14H-ghkMdwOg035yq1cx0mATzl4wkKUO1
will someone with the necessary permissions grant me access to the drive? my email is mrgould93@gmail.com
@technetos will do
also, I just spent a while reviewing the previous survey
I think there is one section we could remove (it asks about upgrading from Rust 2015 to Rust 2018)
but otherwise it's "pretty good"
Yeah I agree removing that section is important
So I guess we could break down the work required here
Has anyone reached out to the translators we used last year?
I have not, that's on my list
well I don't have a list yet
I was just coming to say that I'll try to make one ...
I just created a google folder and shared it with various folks who've historically been involved :)
here is a coordination document
Please grant me access
I did
I thought
no wait
I moved it to the wrong folder :)
ok @technetos try again
Good to go, thanks @nikomatsakis

Has anyone reached out to the translators we used last year?

By the way, I can help with the French translation if needed :slight_smile:
Did that list look about right?
@Santiago Pastorino btw you were heavily involved in coordinating the translation stuff last time, are you interesting/available in doing that again or should we find someone else
also @Manish Goregaokar I'm not sure if you are interested in being involved here
yeah i might be a lil involved but idk if i have the time
Has anyone made any more progress on reaching out to our translators from last year?
also what is the planned end date for the survey?
hey, for some reason I missed Niko's ping about this
I'd prefer if someone else can take care of this effort this time

technetos said:

also what is the planned end date for the survey?

right, that's a good point. Last year it was kept online for ~15 days (from 3rd to 16th Dec.)
https://blog.rust-lang.org/2019/12/03/survey-launch.html
Ive started going through the english version of the 2020 version of the 2019 survey looking for sections that need to be updated for this year, so far all ive found is dates

If nobody else jumps in to contact past year translators, I can offer a bit of time to take care of this (besides helping with translating answers). tbh I still have doubts we can manage a "Survey 2020" properly, but if it's decided, then fine, let's do this :)
Speaking of time, it wouldn't be bad to start shaping now the questions for the Survey 2021. Is a conversation about this already happening somewhere?
Kinda here? :)
cool :-) If someone has already (or thought about) some possible candidate questions for survey 2021, we can start scribbling something on a shared document (e.g. a HackMD)
Regarding translators
@technetos did you make any edits to the 2020 survey?
I made copies of the 2019 surveys but I didn't edit the translations yet
I guess I can reach out to the translators from previous years
Only changed 2019 -> 2020 in the title

Just a reminder that it's important to reach out to the Simplified Chinese translator, since Google Forms is not accessible from China mainland, i think we still need to host the China part of the survey in a Chinese survey web service just like what we did in the previous years.
OK so

hey @llogiq or @jer -- I saw a note in the german translation from last year's survey that says:

Note: Noticeable discrepancies between Englich and German form. Missing questions, etc.

Can one of you review the 2020 German survey to see if that is still the case? (English survey)
If so, that seems like a problem!
My plan for next steps here is:
• Edit and prepare the translations
• Send an e-mail to last year's translators
• Post survey not this thursday but sometime next week
When we do decide the release date, we need to decide how long to run the survey for
Any thoughts?
I was thinking like 2 weeks or someting
it might be interesting to chart how quickly responses fell off last time
if we have that data
It looks like last year we ran the survey for 15 days
image.png
as you might expect, most folks were within 1 week
anyway I don't know how interesting that is but ...
I guess 15 days is ok too
I think a shorter window risks leaving some people out. Additionally, if we really do want to compare last years results to this years, having the same time span makes some sense.
I think we shouldn't go over 14 days
we usually get so many responses too that I'm not too worried about running short
Indeed.
I sent e-mail to the past translators
I realized I did not cc the community team, which I had meant to do
but oh well

Charles Lew said:

Just a reminder that it's important to reach out to the Simplified Chinese translator, since Google Forms is not accessible from China mainland, i think we still need to host the China part of the survey in a Chinese survey web service just like what we did in the previous years.

@Charles Lew I just realized that this means that I can't prepare this survey :)
I guess I better reach out to that translator in particular
OK, I updated all the surveys to say 2020 and deleted section 6, except for simplified chinese.
I'll e-mail that translator specifically now
Hey @technetos / @Manish Goregaokar -- any thoughts on where to reach out for translators beyond the folks who did it in the past?
I will ask around
It looks like the remaining languages we need translators for are Polish and Vietnamese, am I missing any?
I have to update the latest volunteers but polish for sure -- I think I also just gave up on Hindi, I'm not even sure if the survey was up to date or not
last year we had no responses
@nikomatsakis twitter, internals
I can post on internals as a start I guess
I don't really do twitter that much :)
Posted on internals
Someone on Reddit suggested that we could add GitHub as one of the ways that people can stay updated on Rust
